lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct dates and types of weather.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play short weather/date descriptions. Students match each to flashcards or fill in a mini calendar chart with the correct words.
stretchStrategies: Students play “Mystery Calendar & Weather” where one student describes a date and weather, and others guess and write it in their mini calendar charts.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write answers to questions about dates and weather using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Provide question prompts: “What’s the date today?” “What’s the weather like?” Students write full-sentence answers using the SB calendar or visuals.
stretchStrategies: Students play “Mystery Calendar & Weather” where one student describes a date and weather, and others guess and write it in their mini calendar charts.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to play a competitive game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Collaboration) Team game: Students race to complete sentences like “It’s ___ in ___.” Each correct answer earns points.
stretchStrategies: Students play “Mystery Calendar & Weather” where one student describes a date and weather, and others guess and write it in their mini calendar charts.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
